instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: Hey all, have a 00840 on the bench right now that's not booting and has no caps lock/USB activity. Was liquid damaged around <CHIP>U3770</CHIP>, cleaned up with heat and flux. Has proper PPBUS, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>, and <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>. <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> goes high, L7210 stays at 0.98V and doesn't budge.  Checked <RESISTOR>R1320</RESISTOR>-25, all have good resistance values. Have also tried heating CPU with good flux at 180C for 15 seconds, also tried flashing known good BIOS from the forum. Anything else obvious to check, or is this going to be a rabbit hole? Hoping something in the previously affected LCD backlight area hasn't affected the CPU, but everything in that area measures properly comparing to a good board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
Possibly corroded trace, or resistor somewhere.
Can be bad CPU also.

Did you try the board alone on the desk?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: Yeah, same result with just the board on the desk no SSD or anything else. I'll do another pass around the liquid affected areas and see if anything looks out of place or damaged.
